Project Description  The Jilin Water Supply and Sewerage Development Project is a 
key urban infrastructure initiative of the Jilin provincial government 
(JPG). The Project will help (i) reduce water pollution; (ii) protect 
water resources; (iii) address water shortage through recycling 
effluent and meet the demand for high-quality treated water by 
2010; (iv) promote sustainable economic development; and (v) 
improve  the  environment,  living  conditions,  and  public  health 
standards in three cities and one district of Jilin Province. The 
Project  has  five  components  involving  the  improvement  and 
expansion  of  (i)  the  Changchun  wastewater  treatment  and 
sewerage system; (ii) the Shuangyang water supply system; (iii) 
the Changchun Yongchun River flood control capacity; (iv) the 
Liaoyuan water supply system; and (v) the Meihekou water supply 
system. The Project will provide capacity building and training on 
project management, institutional and wastewater management, 
and tariff analysis for all the project implementing agencies (IAs). 
The Project supports the Government’s objectives for the water 
and wastewater sector as set out in the Tenth Five-Year Plan 
(2001–2005), to improve living conditions and health in the project 
cities, and promote their sustainable economic development. 
   
Rationale  The Songhua River Basin (SRB) is the third largest river basin in 
the PRC and intersects Jilin and Heilongjiang provinces and the 
Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The SRB has a catchment 
area of 557,000 square kilometers and a population of 62 million. 
The  Songhua  River is one  of the  most   polluted of the 47 major 
rivers in the PRC, and  is  contaminated with a number  of organic 
  chemicals, heavy metals, and conventional pollutants.

development in the region. The Yitong and Yongchun rivers in 
Changchun, which flow into the SRB, are highly polluted due to

rapid  economic  growth  and  urbanization,  water  pollution  and

Impact and Outcome  The Project will enhance the urban environment, and improve 
public health and quality of life for urban residents in the cities of 
Changchun, Liaoyuan, and Meihekou by increasing wastewater 
coverage and improving the supply of potable water. The outcome 
of the Project will be improved  management and utilization of 
water resources in the SRB by (i) achieving the goal of 70% 
wastewater treatment rate in Changchun by 2010; (ii) solving the 
water  shortage  problem  through  effluent  reuse;  (iii)  increasing 
flood control; (iv) providing a supply of reliable and high-quality 
potable water; (v) reducing the incidence of waterborne diseases 
such as diarrhea and hepatitis A; (vi) increasing the efficiency and 
management capacity of the IAs; (vii) integrating approaches to 
basin-wide pollution prevention and control; and (viii) improving 
cost  recovery  through  a  better  tariff  structure,  with  gradual 
increases to achieve full cost recovery.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the People's Republic of China (PRC) for the Jilin Water Supply and Sewerage Development 
Project. 
 
2.  In line with its long-term goals for the urban sector of improving living conditions and 
expanding the supply of clean water and enhancing wastewater treatment coverage, the PRC 
Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help increase the wastewater 
treatment capacity and provision of clean potable water in the cities of Changchun, Liaoyuan, 
and Meihekou in Jilin Province in northeastern PRC. The Project is consistent with ADB water 
policy1  and  will  help  the  PRC  achieve  the  Millennium  Development  Goals  (MDG)  of 
environmental sustainability and increased access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation. 
This report is based on the findings of the loan appraisal mission and discussions with the 
central and local governments, relevant agencies, and community organizations. The design 
and monitoring framework2 is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
3.  Over the last 20 years, economic growth in the PRC averaged 8% per year and it is 
projected to average 7% over the next 5 years. The urban population increased from about 190 
million in 1980 to about 524 million in 2003, about 40% of the total population. This is expected 
to increase to 700 million or 50% by 2030.3 The Government’s Agenda for Economic Reform 
and  Social  Development  in  the  New  Century  aims  to  accelerate  urbanization  and  the 
development of large, medium, and small cities and small towns. This urbanization process will 
continue to increase the demand for all urban services. In particular, it will place a strain on the 
physical  and  financial  capacity  of  most  cities  to  provide  adequate  water  and  wastewater 
treatment infrastructure. Without significant investment, quality of life for urban residents will 
deteriorate,  the  urban  environment  will  be  degraded,  and  economic  development  will  be 
inefficient.  
 
4.  Municipal water supply in the PRC has increased steadily in the past decade. In 2003, 
total water production was 28.8 billion cubic meters (m3)/day and sales 24.8 billion m3/day, with 
unaccounted for water at 15% of total water production. Industrial and domestic water sales 
account for 35.4% and 56.4% of water sold, while other sales are 8.2%. The national average 
use of water was 365 liters per capita per day and domestic consumption 220 liters per capita 
per day. In most large cities, more than 90% of all urban households have access to piped water 
supply. However, this indicator obscures shortages in many cities of good quality raw water 
supply, water supply delivery capacities, and wastewater treatment facilities. The Government 
has classified more than 300 cities as water-short, with 108 having serious water problems and 
more than 60 being critically short of water. Many of the cities facing water shortages are in 
northern  PRC.  The  per  capita  water  availability  ranges  from  360–750  m3  (lower  than  the 
international definition of water scarcity of 1,000 m3/person). The situation is exacerbated by the

Significant investments are needed to solve the water shortage problems, supply clean drinking 
water, and expand wastewater treatment capacity.

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
8.  Key problems and opportunities include (i) shortage of good quality drinking water; (ii) 
inadequate wastewater treatment capacity; (iii) land subsidence arising from the overuse of 
groundwater; and (iv) the need to assist water supply and wastewater treatment to be self-
financing through tariff reforms. Assistance is required to help the Government achieve the 
MDG for environmental sustainability (MDG goal 7) and to halve the proportion of people 
without sustainable access to safe drinking water and basic sanitation by 2015 (MDG target 10).  
 
1.  Background and Long-Term Plans for the Songhua River Basin 
 
9.  The Songhua River Basin (SRB) is the third largest river basin in the PRC after the 
Yangtze and Yellow rivers. It has an area of 557,000 square kilometers (km2) and a population 
of 62 million. Major cities, such as Harbin and Changchun, and the country’s largest oil fields 
are located in the basin. Agriculture is well developed and the basin has a large industrial base. 
The Songhua river catchment area covers portions of Jilin and Heilongjiang provinces and Inner 
Mongolia Autonomous Region. Changchun is located in the upstream part of the Sonhua River, 
which flows through Harbin. After Harbin, the river joins the Heilongjiang River, enters the 
Russian Federation, and eventually discharges to the sea (Map 1).  
 
10.  The Songhua River is one of the most polluted of the 47 major rivers in the PRC. It is 
contaminated with a number of organic chemicals, heavy metals, and conventional pollutants 
that result mainly from the discharge of untreated or partially treated wastewater, primarily from 
industries upstream from Harbin. The river is classified by the Government as class IV (falling 
below class V during the 6-month, low-flow winter season), and is considered unsuitable for 
municipal domestic water use. The river water parameters consistently fail to meet PRC class III 
standards, the minimum water quality required for the water to be used as a raw water source 
for water supply. In March 2003, ADB approved the Harbin Water Supply Project for $100 
million to address the needs of Harbin city (population of 3 million) for clean and reliable drinking 
water from an alternative water source (Lalin River), since their existing source—the Songhua 
River—was highly polluted. Because of the deteriorating water quality in the Songhua River, the 
Harbin Municipal Government is expediting construction of the project, which is on track to be 
completed ahead of the original schedule.9 From 2001 to 2005, Heilongjiang Province has taken 
concrete actions to reduce pollution into the SRB, immediately upstream of Harbin City, namely, 
from the cities of Daqing and Qiqihar. Daqing City constructed a 50,000 m3/day wastewater 
treatment plant (WWTP) in 2001, and a second WWTP with a capacity of 80,000 m3/day will be

2.  Project Rationale  
 
11.  Changchun, the capital of Jilin Province, has an urban population of 3 million. It is 
located in the upper reaches of the SRB, between the provinces of Heilongjiang and Liaoning. 
The rivers in Changchun (Yitong and Yongchun rivers), which flow into the Songhua River, are 
highly polluted due to inadequate treatment of wastewater discharge. Jilin Province, therefore, 
has a critical role to play in wastewater management in the upstream of the SRB. The current 
water quality in the Yitong and Yongchun rivers does not meet class V of the national water 
quality standards; this has caused severe pollution of the Songhua River, and poses a threat to 
public health of the urban population and downstream users. Changchun has inadequate water 
supply and wastewater treatment. Further, water shortage is expected to reach 360,000 m3/day 
by  2010  and  water  rationing  is  sometimes  implemented.  Changchun’s  current  wastewater 
treatment capacity of 565,000 m3/day is inadequate and has already resulted in heavy pollution 
of  the  Yitong  and  Yongchun  rivers.  To  meet  future  demands,  this  capacity  needs  to  be 
increased to 803,000 m3/day by 2010 and 1,700,000 m3/day by 2020. The sewer network and 
wastewater treatment capacity in Changchun must be expanded to improve water quality in the 
Yitong and Yongchun rivers. Through the Project, the discharge of untreated wastewater in the 
upstream  of  the  SRB  will  be  significantly  reduced.  The  Project  will  also  contribute  to  the 
Changchun municipal government (CMG) goal of achieving a wastewater treatment rate of 70% 
by 2010. The Project’s rationale is consistent with the ADB water policy, which aims to foster 
integrated management of water resources from a river basin perspective.

4.  Lessons Learned 
 
18.  ADB has provided more than $1.7 billion in loans for wastewater and water supply 
projects in the PRC (Appendix 4). Loan projects have generally been implemented well. During 
project processing, lessons of experience were addressed by (i) thoroughly evaluating the 
technical designs and technologies; (ii) ensuring an adequate debt-equity ratio for the project 
IAs; (iii) undertaking rigorous sensitivity analysis of cash flows, and financial and economic 
analysis; and (iv) incorporating institutional strengthening measures to improve the level of 
corporate governance.  
 
19.  Lessons learned from ADB postevaluation experience in water supply and sanitation 
highlight the importance of integrating both supply and demand concerns into project design. 
Encouraging broad reforms, such as commercial management, and introducing competition will 
promote efficient and responsive delivery of water supply and wastewater services. Appropriate 
pricing policies for water and sanitation services are also required. Lessons learned include (i) 
the importance of a thorough review of technical designs; (ii) the need for strategic master plans 
in urban development and environmental management; (iii) consideration of local conditions and 
constraints;  (iv)  the  importance  of  measures  to  support  financial  reform,  particularly  in 
establishing autonomous wastewater entities and tariff increases; (v) the need for institutional 
strengthening,  particularly  in  establishing  managerial  autonomy;  (vi)  the  need  to  address 
regulatory and enforcement issues; (vii) the importance of public education on environmental 
improvement; (viii) the need to provide training to utility personnel; (ix) better public consultation 
and community participation; (x) early attention to resettlement issues; and (xi) the need to 
support public-private partnerships in water supply and wastewater treatment.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
20.  The Project will enhance the urban environment and improve public health15 and quality 
of life for urban residents in the cities of Changchun, Liaoyuan, and Meihekou, by increasing 
wastewater coverage and improving the supply of potable water. The outcome of the Project will 
be improved management and utilization of water resources in the SRB by (i) achieving the goal 
of  70%  wastewater  treatment  rate  in  Changchun  by  2010;  (ii)  solving  the  water  shortage 
problem through effluent reuse; (iii) increasing flood control; (iv) providing a supply of reliable 
and high-quality potable water; (v) reducing the incidence of waterborne diseases such as 
diarrhea and hepatitis A; (vi) increasing the efficiency and management capacity of the IAs;16 
(vii) integrating approaches for basinwide pollution prevention and control; and (viii) improving 
cost  recovery  through  a  better  tariff  structure,  with  gradual  increases  to  achieve  full  cost 
recovery.  
 
B.  Outputs 
 
21.  The Project has five physical components that involve the improvement and expansion of 
the (i) Changchun wastewater treatment and sewerage system, (ii) Shuangyang water supply 
system, (iii) Changchun Yongchun River flood control capacity, (iv) Liaoyuan water supply 
system, and (v) Meihekou water supply system. The Project also includes capacity building 
(Supplementary Appendix A) to support project management and implementation, by improving 
the capabilities of the project management office (PMO) and implementing agencies (IAs). The 
detailed description of the physical components is given Supplementary Appendix B.  
 
22.  The  improvement  and  expansion  of  wastewater  services  in  Changchun  includes  (i) 
upgrading the existing Beijiao primary WWTP to secondary treatment with a capacity of 130,000 
m3/day including recycling of treated wastewater; (ii) constructing sewerage pipelines, pumping 
stations, and maintenance and management stations; and (iii) constructing a 150,000 m3/day 
Nanjiao WWTP including recycling of treated wastewater. These improvements will result in 
70% of the wastewater treated and wastewater services coverage increased to 85% of the 
urban population in Changchun by 2010. The improvement and expansion of the Shuangyang 
water supply system involves constructing a WTP with a capacity of 36,000 m3/day, with a 
related  water  pumping  station  to  extract  surface  water  from  Shuanyuang  reservoir,  and 
pipelines to convey treated water from the WTP to the district’s distribution network.  
 
23.  The  Changchun  Yongchun  River  flood  control  improvement  component  involves 
improving the dam and spillway of the Sanjia reservoir, widening the Yongchun River, and 
constructing seven new box culverts.

C.  Special Features 
 
27.  The funding of the Project directly from water and wastewater tariffs is a major reform in 
line with the ADB water policy. This is expected to reduce water consumption and increase 
recycling of industrial water. ADB involvement in the Project, coupled with water tariff increases, 
is expected to have a catalytic effect in attracting future private sector participation. Recycling 
wastewater at a rate of 150,000 m3/day will have two significant benefits: reduce water pollution 
and address water shortage problems. Further, the demonstration of a successful wastewater 
recycling subproject will encourage replication of similar optimal and cost-effective approaches 
to address water pollution and water shortage.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
 
A.  Project Benefits and Impacts 
 
44.  The Project will benefit about 3 million urban residents whose living conditions and 
public  health  standards  will  be  improved  due  to  (i)  improved  quality  of  water  supply  and 
wastewater services, protection from flooding, and elimination of hazards associated with poor 
drainage; and (ii) reduction in the incidence of waterborne diseases such as diarrhea and

15 
hepatitis A, below 2003 levels in Changchun, Liaoyuan, and Meihekou (to be monitored through 
the project performance management system). The Project will result in improved management 
and utilization of water resources in the upper SRB by (i) achieving the goal of 70% wastewater 
treatment rate in Changchun by 2010; (ii) solving the water shortage problem through effluent 
reuse, which can be used beneficially for industry or irrigation; (iii) increasing flood control; (iv) 
providing a supply of reliable and high-quality potable water; (v) increasing the efficiency and 
management  capacity  of  the  IAs;  and  (vi)  improving  cost  recovery  through  a  better  tariff 
structure, with gradual increases to achieve full cost recovery. The water quality improvements 
in the SRB will also contribute to integrated water resource management and pollution control; 
the basinwide management program; and transboundary pollution prevention and control. 
 
45.  The Project will secure the provision of clean and reliable water supply to Changchun, 
Liaoyuan  and  Meihekou,  by  developing  drinking  water  sources  from  rivers  and  existing 
reservoirs, instead of relying solely on groundwater that is overexploited and has reached 
unsustainable  levels.  The  proposed  extension,  replacement,  and  rehabilitation  of  water 
distribution systems will increase the proportion of the population with access to piped water 
supplies. These improvements in the distribution system will reduce water losses and reduce 
the risk of contamination of treated water within the distribution system. Recycling wastewater 
will reduce water pollution and address the water shortage problem. The Project will improve 
flood  control  by  improving  the  drainage  systems,  separating  the  storm-water  drains  and 
sewerage networks, and strengthening the dam and spillway of the existing Sanjia reservoir. 
This will minimize loss of life and damage to property, agriculture, and infrastructure. The 
extraction of groundwater will be reduced to sustainable levels, thus reducing land subsidence.  
The reliable supply of water will reduce the burden on women responsible for domestic duties 
and caring for the sick.

2.  Poverty Reduction and Social Benefits 
 
50.  The Project will benefit about 3 million urban people in Changchun, Liaoyuan, and 
Meihekou,  through  the  provision  of  clean  water,  expansion  of  wastewater  capacity,  and 
increased  flood  protection.  Of  the total  beneficiary  population,  about  210,000  or  7.0%  are 
classified as poor measured by the weighted average local urban poverty line of CNY1,875 per 
year. The Project will support poverty reduction by (i) providing safer and more reliable urban 
water supplies; (ii) improving the natural environment by increased wastewater treatment; (iii) 
reducing morbidity due to decreased exposure to waterborne diseases such as diarrhea and 
hepatitis A; (iv) reducing risk of frequent local flooding by improving collection and disposal of 
wastewater and storm water; (v) reducing the risk of major flooding through river training and 
reservoir rehabilitation works; and (vi) providing employment opportunities for the poor.  
 
51.  The  Project  will  improve  public  health  by  reducing  waterborne  diseases  through 
improved water supply, expanded wastewater capacity, and increased flood protection. An 
order of magnitude analysis of the impact on morbidity and mortality was completed for the 
Project (Supplementary Appendix H). The Project is expected to reduce disease episodes by an 
average of 8,000 cases per year. One in 20 of these cases, or 400 cases, is likely to be serious 
enough to result in a medical consultation. Provision of clean water will improve the quality of 
life of the poor and vulnerable by reducing the proportion of household income spent on medical 
treatment for waterborne diseases. The number of school days and workdays lost due to 
sickness will also be reduced. Further, the Project will reduce the proportion of household 
income spent on buying water from private sources and buying storage containers, filters, and 
other water-cleaning equipment. Water pressure improvements will greatly enhance the quality 
of life of households living in apartments and reduce their water-pumping costs. Improved water 
supply will significantly reduce the time, cost, and labor that mainly women spend on collecting 
water, cleaning containers, and improving water quality. The increased flood control will reduce 
the risk of infection from overflowing sewers during the flooding season.

C.  Financial Aspects 
 
54.  The financial evaluation of the Project was undertaken in real terms using constant 2004 
prices. The project cost estimates and financial projections in nominal terms were converted to 
real terms by adjusting for the projected effects of foreign and domestic inflation and currency 
fluctuation. Incremental benefits and costs were derived by evaluating the financial position of 
the IAs under with- and without-project scenarios. The financial internal rate of return for the 
Project  was  computed  on  an  after-tax  basis  of  6.2%,  which  compares  favorably  with  the 
weighted average cost of capital in real terms of 1.9%. The financial analysis is in Appendix 12.  
 
55.  The sensitivity analysis includes examination of the risk that project costs will increase by 
10%, or that revenues will be depressed by a 1-year delay in tariff adjustments; the resulting 
financial internal rates of return are 5.3% and 5.5%, respectively. Detailed verification of the 
local financing plan indicate that the equity contributions from CMG, LMG, and MMG are about 
1%, 1.3%, and 1.5% of annual revenues respectively, indicating minimal risk. CMG, LMG, and 
MMG have sufficient financial resources to take on responsibility for guaranteeing the loan 
repayments, and have provided assurances that they accept this risk. An affordability analysis 
has been undertaken, based on proposed tariffs and household income data from the social 
survey. Tariffs under the Project are considered affordable if the combined average water and 
wastewater charges are less than 5% of household income. The estimated tariffs on this basis 
are affordable to the average household (2.0% of income), and also affordable to the poorest 
10%  of  households  (less  than  3.4%  of  income  before  accounting  for  poverty  reduction 
measures that exist now or that have been committed to).

included as loan covenants covering capital structure (debt to equity), debt service cover, and

F.  Project Risks and Mitigation Measures 
 
61.  The  Project  does  not  have  any  unusual  technical  risks.  The  water  supply  and 
wastewater  subprojects  have  adopted  conventional  engineering  design  and  treatment 
processes that are robust and with proven records of reliable performance. The ICB equipment 
procurement packages will include technical support for installation, testing, and commissioning 
as  recommended  by  the  manufacturer.  During  project  implementation,  internationally 
experienced  consultants  will  provide  support  to  the  PMOs,  PIUs,  and  IAs  to  ensure  the 
delivered equipment and works comply with the design requirements and quality standards. 
Based on the performance of ADB’s PRC portfolio, cost overruns and major implementation 
delays are not expected.  
 
62.  Potential risks in developing a strong water supply and wastewater utility include: (i) 
future constraints on institutional reforms; and (ii) lack of adequate public support to increase 
water supply tariffs and wastewater charges to meet cost recovery targets. These risks have 
been mitigated by: (i) assurances from CMG, LMG and MMG on the financial and managerial 
autonomy of the IAs; (ii) local programs to mitigate the impact of tariff increases on poor 
households; and (iii) the diversity and frequency of public participation conducted to date, which 
the IAs are committed to continue, in combination with regular tariff reviews and oversight of 
local price bureaus. Potential financial and commercial risks related to the project include (i) 
failure to meet the cash/equity transfers required to construct the Project; (ii) failure of the 
Shuangyang Tap Water Company and Meihekou Reservoir Management Bureau to honor the 
WPA; (iii) constraints on institutional reform of water supply and drainage companies; and (iv) 
failure by the IAs to increase the tariffs to meet cost recovery targets. The potential financial and 
policy risks will be mitigated by assurances related to the financial and managerial autonomy for 
water supply and drainage companies.  The risks associated with lack of local funding will be 
addressed by the assurance from CMG, LMG, and MMG that they (i) would meet whatever cost 
increases are incurred, and (ii) provide a guarantee on the required equity injections to meet the 
financing requirements and financial ratios of the project.

WATER SUPPLY AND WASTEWATER SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  The National Policy and Regulatory Framework 
 
1.  Until recently, the Government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) was the sole 
provider  of  urban  services.  Wastewater  management  practice  was  based  on  septic  tanks, 
designated  open  drainage  ditches,  and  no  treatment.  Services  were  funded  through  tax 
revenue, with minimum or no charges levied on consumers. With rapid economic growth and 
urban expansion, the Government recognized the need for environmental protection measures 
to be implemented alongside economic growth policies to meet its vision of clean, modern, and 
environmentally sustainable cities that would be competitive in the global market place. As a 
result, the Government made a fundamental shift to a market-based approach and enterprise 
provision  in  the  delivery  of  infrastructure  services  and  an  integrated  approach  to  urban 
management. 
 
2.  The Water Pollution and Prevention Law (1996) authorizes the setting of standards for 
ambient  surface  water  quality1  and  uses  these  standards  to  set  targets  for  individual 
watercourses. The State Environment Protection Agency (SEPA) defines the technical national 
standards, including standards that apply to sections of rivers or other watercourses of strategic 
significance.  For  other  rivers  and  watercourses,  the  relevant  municipal  or  provincial 
environmental protection department sets the targeted water quality class. 
 
3.  The water sector continues to be a priority sector in the Tenth Five-Year Plan. The 
Government’s strategy focuses on (i) developing water sources; (ii) protecting existing sources 
by controlling industrial and residential pollution in rivers, lakes, and reservoirs; (iii) controlling 
overextraction  from  groundwater  resources;  and  (iv)  improving  demand  management  by 
introducing technologies that enhance the efficiency of water operations, and using appropriate 
pricing mechanisms. Guidelines for urban water supply emphasize (i) proper planning and the 
inclusion of water supply projects in national, provincial, and municipal economic development 
plans; (ii) mobilizing financial resources from users and from various Government sources for 
the construction of new facilities; (iii) full cost recovery from industrial and commercial users, 
and recovery of operation and maintenance costs from residential users; (iv) use of loans and 
credit to finance urban water supply; and (v) application of new technology where appropriate. 
The  Government  is  increasingly  concerned  about  the  need  for  policy  reform  and  capacity 
building to improve water resource management, and to introduce cost-recovery techniques and 
capability to enable water delivery programs to be financially self-sustaining. Also, because of 
the severity of urban environmental problems, the Government has made cities the focal point 
of its environment protection efforts.  
 
4.  The  Government’s  successive  5-year  plans  have  set  targets  and  requirements  for 
achieving  the  designated  water  quality  classes.  Provincial  and  municipal  governments  are 
called upon to draw up specific plans to address wastewater collection, treatment, and disposal. 
Regulations are provided for effluent standards for industries prior to discharge to a municipal 
sewer.  Industries  are  required  to  provide  adequate  wastewater  treatment  to  meet  specific 
regulatory pollution limits. For municipal wastewater, the level of treatment is determined by the 
water quality class of the receiving water and specific target treatment rates. A target in the

B.  Wastewater Management  
 
5.  Progress in environmental management was made during the Ninth Five-Year Plan 
(1995–2000). By 1999 the total discharge volume of major pollutants, including chemical oxygen 
demand and petroleum-related products, declined by 15–25% compared with 1995 levels. Much 
of the progress was made in industrial pollution in line with Government policy to target major 
point source polluters first. Many polluting industries were closed down and others undertook 
investment  in  on-site  wastewater  treatment,  including  some  supported  by  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). Investment also took place in municipal treatment plants. By 2002, 
about 537 municipal WWTPs were treating approximately 35.8 million m3/day. 
 
6.  In 2003, wastewater generated was 46 billion m3/year. Growth in domestic3 wastewater 
generation  (about  65%  of  the  total)  is  outweighing  the  reductions  achieved  in  industrial 
wastewater (about 35%). Currently about 40% of the total wastewater generated is treated, 
leaving an annual volume of over 20 billion m3 of untreated wastewater. In the absence of a 
municipal  WWTP,  a  mixture  of  raw  domestic  wastewater  and  partially  treated  industrial 
wastewater is discharged from the municipal sewer into the nearest body of water. Designated 
open wastewater ditches are still common in many cities. Municipal wastewater is a major 
contributor to the pollution of rivers and lakes, with the most severe pollution impacts in the 
water-short northern region of the country. 
 
7.  In regional and higher level cities, only 30% of rivers meet their designated water quality 
standards compared with the Tenth Five-Year Plan objective of 60%. In seven major river 
basins,4 52% of rivers do not meet the class III standard required for sources of potable water. 
More than half the rivers in urban areas are the lowest quality—class V or below. About 16% 
are at the lowest class V standard, and 36% are worse than class V standard. Eutrophication is 
occurring in three quarters of major fresh water lakes. Surface water sources serving municipal 
water supply systems are polluted to levels unacceptable under water quality standards. The 
water  quality  in  groundwater  aquifers  is  deteriorating.  Much  more  investment  in  collection 
systems and municipal WWTPs is needed. WWTPs are the key to water pollution control, since 
industrial treatment plants typically provide only pretreatment to a low effluent standard, prior to 
discharge  to  a  municipal  sewer.  Social  surveys  demonstrate  that  the  urban  population  is 
becoming  increasingly  concerned  about  the  impact  of  wastewater  pollution.  Although 
wastewater companies have been established in many cities, few are financially or managerially 
autonomous/ and tariff increases have been slow to be implemented.

D.  Performance Indicators 
 
10.  SRB water quality is managed through legally established targets for water quality: five 
classes plus a residual class for water bodies with quality below the lowest class. Yitong River 
receives Changchun’s domestic and industrial wastewater. The water quality of the section of 
Yitong River downstream of Changchun has been characterized as class V, based on water 
quality monitoring data for this Project. Major pollutants are chemical oxygen demand (COD), 
biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), ammonia nitrogen (NH3-N), and petroleum hydrocarbon. 
 
11.  Currently, about 677,300 m3/day of wastewater is collected in the five urban built-up 
district areas of Changchun. The total capacity of the existing municipal wastewater treatment 
plants is 540,000 m3/day; however, one (Beijiao treatment plant of capacity 390,000 m3/day) is a 
primary treatment plant, and the treated wastewater does not meet secondary effluent standard. 
The actual secondary wastewater treatment rate in Changchun is estimated to be 22.15%, while 
the remaining untreated wastewater is discharged into rivers causing major pollution. 
 
E.  Institutional Framework: Laws, Policies, and Government Agencies 
 
12.  The institutional framework for managing surface water quality in the SRB includes (i) 
legal standards and targets for surface water quality; and (ii) policies, regulations, and plans to 
meet the targets. The 1996 Water Pollution and Prevention Law authorized setting national 
standards for surface water quality, and using these standards to set targets for individual 
watercourses. The law empowers SEPA to define national technical standards. 
 
13.  The standards of surface water quality are set according to the intended use of the 
water. Classes I, II, and III apply to surface water for drinking. Classes IV and V are for surface 
water for irrigation or industry. Each class is defined by 30 criteria, prescribing numeric ranges 
for the physical, chemical, and biological properties of water (such as temperature, pH, and 
coliform counts). Once SEPA defined the water quality classes, desired or targeted ambient 
water quality was determined for each river reach. SEPA set the desired or targeted ambient 
water quality for some strategic river reaches but, more generally, either the municipal or 
provincial environmental protection department set the targeted water quality class.  
 
14.  To  help  address  pollution  of  the  SRB,  ADB  provided  the  SRB  Water  Quality  and 
Pollution Control Management technical assistance. A key objective is to help develop an SRB 
pollution control plan that includes a list of prioritized wastewater and sewerage development 
projects that would contribute to pollution control in the SRB.

7.  CMG, LMG, and MMG recognize that provision of adequate facilities for wastewater 
treatment is essential for public health. This treatment must be undertaken incrementally and in 
phases because of the high cost involved. The success of wastewater management policy will 
impact on the sector objective of pollution reduction and also on the cost-effectiveness of 
wastewater management and operations. The incremental wastewater treatment capacity that 
will be added will exceed the incremental water supply in the project area. 
 
E.  Cost Recovery and Tariff Reform 
8.  The Project will support the Government’s ongoing economic and enterprise reform 
programs that require all water supply and wastewater management projects to be financially 
sustainable and capable of cost recovery. Water supply companies (WSCs) are required to 
improve their cost-recovery capability. Appropriate mechanisms for tariff setting are a critical 
factor in attracting the needed investment to the sector, ending WSC reliance on government 
subsidies and providing incentives to users to conserve water resources.  
 
9.  ADB is actively encouraging this transition in its policy dialogue and lending operations. 
Two ADB water tariff studies support the Government’s initiatives. A major output of the first TA 
was  the  National  Guidelines  on  Water  Tariffs  (NGWT),  subsequently  promulgated  by  the 
National  Development  and  Reform  Commission  (NDRC)  and  the  Ministry  of  Construction 
(MOC)  in  September  1998.  Major  features  in  the  NGWT  that  reflect  specific  TA 
recommendations include: (i) selecting a tariff structure based on local conditions and priorities, 
(ii) considering a two-part tariff with a volumetric charge and fixed demand charge, (iii) adopting 
full cost recovery as the main objective in setting and approving tariff levels, (iv) use of the 
public hearings mechanism to disseminate tariff increase plans to the public and obtain their 
feedback; and (v) adopting a simplified process for tariff regulation, requiring evaluation and 
approval by the municipal government and supported by provincial and national review and 
monitoring. The NGWT improved the long-term financial viability of the WSCs, and provided for 
operation, maintenance, and service expansion, which in turn will help increase private sector 
participation in the water sector.  
 
10.  The  second  water  tariff  study  TA  focused  on  helping  the  Government  develop 
institutional and methodological capacities to implement the NGWT. The TA helped prepare the 
draft local implementing regulations of the NGWT for Zhangjiakou, Fuzhou, and Chengdu. 
Enactment of a local tariff regulation provides a legal basis for regulating water tariffs and 
ensures transparency and efficiency. The Zhangjiakou Implementation Regulations, approved

by the Zhangjiakou municipal government in September 2000, were the first local water tariff 
regulation under the NGWT. The Chengdu Implementation Regulations were issued in 2002. 
Public hearing meetings are a mandatory requirement of the NGWT. The TA advocated the use 
of  hearings  to  obtain  the  views  of  the  public  on  water  supply  and  to  promote  public 
understanding of WSCs, policies, and efforts to develop improved water supply services. Based

recommendations, including the achievements in Zhangjiakou, have been acknowledged by the 
State Council as a good example of tariff reform. NDRC issued a notice to local governments 
nationwide indicating that the Zhangjiakou water tariff reforms were recognized as a good 
example for undertaking tariff reforms required by the NGWT. On 1 April 2002, upon completion 
of  the  study,  MOC,  Ministry  of  Finance,  Ministry  of  Water  Resources,  NDRC,  and  SEPA 
officially issued a notice on strengthening urban water tariff reforms; this was followed on 9 April 
2002 by a nationwide video conference to discuss the Zhangjiakou experience on water tariff 
reforms. Nationwide replication of the Zhangjiakou tariff reforms model is ongoing. Generation 
of funds for future expansion and rehabilitation of water supply and wastewater systems directly 
from  tariff  increases  is  gaining  momentum  and  having  a  positive  impact  on  the  financial 
sustainability of WSCs and wastewater utility agencies.  
 
11.  Specific impacts of the overall package of reforms are best illustrated by the benefits in 
Zhangjiakou. The benefits include (i) the Price Bureau's lead role in tariff administration was 
clearly  established;  (ii)  the  water  supply  administration  of  the  Public  Utility  Bureau  was 
streamlined; (iii) a financial plan was in place for the Zhangjiakou Water Supply Company to 
service the debt within a reasonable time frame, while recovering other costs and earning 
profits;  (iv)  the  Zhangjiakou  municipal  government  has  funds  to  repay  international  and 
domestic loans within 6 years and will have funds for future development; (v) the construction 
commission, which is responsible for Zhangjiakou's new water treatment plant, has the funding 
required to finish its work; (vi) proposed tariffs are affordable for domestic customers, and poor 
households benefit from a new program to provide relief from cost of their water bills; (vii) public 
hearings make the tariff approval process transparent, encourage cost control and service 
improvements, promote understanding of the importance of tariff increases, and help support 
tariff  adjustments;  (viii)  the  institutional  capacity  to  control  costs  and  tariff  increases  was 
strengthened; and (ix) water conservation was improved by tariff increases and an appropriate 
tariff structure. Multiyear tariff adjustment proposals such as the one developed for Zhangjiakou 
will result in other benefits. First, the underlying financial plan for the proposal provides the basis 
of a service contract between the municipality and the WSC, which can serve as a tool to 
control costs. Second, the long-term financial planning provides a framework to attract private 
investors. 
  
12.  JPG, CMG, LMG, and MMG confirmed that they were implementing the NGWT. CMG, 
LMG, and MMG have been increasing water and wastewater tariffs in keeping with the state 
government  policies  to  promote  better  cost  recovery.  Between  1999  and  2004,  aggregate 
domestic tariffs (water plus wastewater) have increased by 194% in Changchun,8 150% in 
Liaoyuan, and 70% in Meihekou. Corresponding increases in industrial tariffs have been 66%, 
50%, and 15%. A water supply and wastewater tariff increase policy will be issued by December 
2005 for 2006–2009.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The financial analysis was prepared in accordance with Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
Guidelines for the Financial Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by 
ADB.1 Details of the financial analysis and financial projections are in Supplementary Appendix 
F. An assessment of financial performance was completed for operations once the Project is 
implemented. The assessment was completed for the implementing agencies (IAs) that operate 
as enterprises.  
 
B.  Financial Internal Rate of Return and Sensitivity Analysis 
 
1.  Purpose and Approach 
 
2.  The project evaluation assessed the financial performance of the IAs following project 
implementation. The evaluation is completed for those IAs that will operate project components 
on a self-financing basis based on tariff revenues. These IAs and their associated project 
components are identified. The evaluation determines the level of cost recovery from users that 
is required to service the ADB loan and achieve financial health.  
 
3.  Key  features  of  the  financial  evaluation  include  (i)  financial  evaluations  of  project 
components were carried out in real terms using 2004 prices; (ii) financial internal rate of return 
(FIRR) was determined using incremental annual cash flows over 25years of operations; (iii) 
residual value of physical assets is assumed to equal its remaining book or depreciated value at 
the end of the evaluation period; (iv) evaluation was carried out for the project components and 
the combination of project components that feature cost recovery through tariffs; and (v) all cost 
and revenue projections were prepared using a pro forma financial modeling approach.  
 
2.  Weighted Average Cost of Capital 
4.  The weighted average cost of capital (WACC) was calculated in real terms for the 
Project. Funding sources for the Project are the ADB loan (43%), a local bank loan (3%), and 
capital contributions from local governments (54%). The cost of foreign debt was calculated 
based on a nominal interest rate of 5.14%, an income tax rate of 33%, and an international 
inflation rate of 1.5% per annum. The real cost of foreign debt was estimated to be 1.59%. The 
cost of local debt was calculated based on a nominal interest rate of 6.21%, income tax rate of 
33%, and domestic inflation rate of 2.7% per annum. The real cost of local debt was estimated 
to be 2.29%. The WACC was determined to be 1.90% for the base case analysis.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Identification of Projects and Analysis of Alternatives 
1.  The Jilin Water Supply and Sewerage Development Project was identified in the Tenth 
Five-Year  Plan  (2001–2005)  as  the  least  cost  alternative  to  addressing  the  wastewater 
treatment and water supply needs in the cities of Changchun, Liaoyuan, and Meihekou in Jilin 
Province.  During  the  design  of  the  Project,  alternative  locations  and  specifications  for  the 
wastewater treatment plant, sewer networks, water treatment plants, pumping stations, and raw 
water transmission and distribution mains were considered within the project area. The detailed 
economic analysis and least cost analysis are in Supplementary Appendix J. 
 
B.  Economic Parameters and Assumptions 
2.  An economic analysis of the Project was conducted over 25 years inclusive of project 
construction.  Project  construction  commences  in  2005  and  is  completed  in  2009,  while 
commissioning commences in 2010. Economic benefits and costs were denominated in terms 
of the domestic price numeraire and expressed in constant 2004 prices. International costs were 
converted to local currency costs using an exchange rate that started at CNY8.26 per $1, and 
were adjusted annually based on a purchasing power parity assumption. Project costs and 
benefits were estimated on a without- and with-project basis appropriately apportioned on the 
basis  of  nonincremental  and  incremental  project  effects  in  accordance  with  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects and Handbook for 
the  Economic  Analysis  of  Water  Supply  Projects.  Tradable  components  were  adjusted  to 
economic prices using a shadow exchange rate factor of 1.013, and nontraded components 
were valued at domestic market prices. A shadow wage rate factor of 2.0 and 0.67 was applied 
to the wage of skilled and unskilled labor respectively at the domestic price level.  
 
C.  Costs 
3.  Base costs plus physical contingencies of the Project and each of the subproject capital 
costs were estimated and apportioned on the basis of tradable, nontradable, and skilled and 
unskilled labor costs. Similarly, operation and maintenance costs for each subproject and the 
overall Project were estimated, apportioned on the basis of tradable and nontradable works, 
consumables, services, equipment and machinery, and skilled and unskilled labor valued in 
economic prices, i.e., shadow wage rate factors. Additional conversion factors were used as 
necessary. Transfer payments were excluded in the valuation of the cost estimates in economic 
prices. Physical contingencies were added to capital costs.  
 
D.  Project Benefits 
4.  The Project’s primary benefits include 
 
(i)  improved wastewater collection and treatment services in Changchun; 
(ii)  provision of an alternative low-cost supply of water for industrial users based on 
reuse of treated wastewater effluent; 
(iii)  reduced flood damage on the Yongchun River in Changchun;  
(iv)  improved  water  supply  treatment  and  distribution  services  in,  Liaoyuan, 
Meihekou, and Shuangyang; and 
(v)  improved local drainage works to reduce local flooding in Liaoyuan.

1.  Water Supply Benefits 
 
5.  Benefits associated with the improved water supply treatment and distribution services 
include the provision of 24-hour service in areas currently experiencing interrupted service, 
improvements in system pressure, increased security of supply, improved drinking water quality, 
reduced risk of exposure to waterborne pathogens in delivered tap water, and reductions in 
nonrevenue water.  
 
6.  Indirect benefits of a 24-hour service for domestic beneficiaries include the elimination of 
financial  costs  incurred  to  cope  with  the  interrupted  water  supply  service,  elimination  of 
disruptions including loss of employment opportunity, and a general enhancement of the quality 
of life. Nondomestic water supply customers will benefit financially due to lower costs and fewer 
disruptions to production.  
 
7.  Water supply benefits are estimated using a willingness-to-pay approach. Water supply 
customers were asked to state their willingness-to-pay for service improvements and their 
revealed willingness-to-pay is used to measure benefit to customers. Provided that customers 
are  well  informed,  the  amount  of  willingness-to-pay  represents  a  value  for  all  anticipated 
benefits, including reduced health risk.  
 
8.  The  economic  benefits  for  water  supply  improvements  were  estimated  for  the 
incremental annual water demand over the 25-year period of analysis. Average benefits for 
project components were estimated to be 
 
(i)  Liaoyuan: CNY 4.7/ cubic meter (m3); 
(ii)  Meihekou: CNY 7.3/m3; and 
(iii)  Shuangyang: CNY 8.8/m3. 
 
2.  Wastewater Benefits 
9.  The impacts associated with improvements in wastewater collection and treatment and 
the effluent reuse scheme in  Changchun include (i) lower ongoing discharge of untreated 
wastewater to receiving streams, (ii) reduced frequency of acute surface water contamination 
due to combined sewer overflows, and (iii) reduced hydraulic loading of treated wastewater 
effluent to receiving streams. Benefits that flow from these impacts include (i) improved aquatic 
environment in local streams and downstream in the Songhua River, (ii) reduced risk of human 
and livestock exposure to waterborne pathogens in surface waters, (iii) reduced transboundary 
aquatic pollution in the Songhua River Basin, (iv) provision of low-cost water for industrial uses, 
and (v) enhanced sustainability of drinking water supplies for Changchun.  
 
10.  Two approaches are used to evaluate these benefits. The first considers the wastewater 
components within the broader context of urban, provincial, and national policies and objectives 
for wastewater management and water quality control. Assuming these policies and objectives 
reflect social choice, the basic requirement is that the Project be a least cost option that 
contributes to achievement of the policy objectives.1 The second entails a quantitative analysis 
based on willingness to pay for wastewater improvements. This analysis can only capture a 
portion  of  project  benefits  since  it  only  considers  urban  wastewater  service  customers  in 
Changchun and not downstream beneficiaries.

11.  The national policy for pollution control endorses the use of cost-effective wastewater 
management measures to achieve overall treatment targets. Under guidelines from the Ministry 
of Construction,2 major cities like Changchun should achieve a wastewater treatment rate of 
70%  by  2010.  In  its  Tenth  Five-Year  Plan  for  Environmental  Protection,  Jilin  Province 
established a water quality target: by 2010, 85% of the Songhua River Basin river network 
would achieve at least a class III standard. This target is to be achieved primarily through 
improved wastewater treatment. Changchun’s target for water quality in the Yitong River is class 
III by 2010. 
 
12.  At present, the Yitong River, which receives the majority of Changchun wastewater 
flows, has class V water quality downstream of Changchun. Almost 60% of the Songhua River 
was in class IV or V in 2002 and 40% of the river by length was class III. The proposed 
wastewater  works  are  therefore  consistent  with  provincial  plans.  Proposed  works  are  also 
consistent with the Changchun City Urban Master Plan (1996–2020) and its Water Supply and 
Sewage Master Plan. 
 
13.  The quantitative analysis of wastewater benefits is based on customer willingness to pay 
for  wastewater  improvements  provided  in  response  to  a  household  survey.3  The  average 
willingness to pay was estimated to be CNY0.50 per m3 of metered water use. This amount 
represents the incremental amount customers would willingly pay through their water bill in 
return for the benefits associated with proposed wastewater improvements. It is an estimate of 
benefit  for  the  urban  population  but  does  not  reflect  the  value  of  these  improvements  to 
downstream beneficiaries. The calculation of economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for the 
Changchun wastewater component is therefore an understatement of the true EIRR. 
 
14.  Wastewater benefits in Changchun will be offset in part by increases in wastewater 
discharges associated with water supply system improvements in Liaoyuan, Meihekou, and 
Shuangyang.  In  all  three  cases,  water  demand  will  increase  significantly  in  response  to 
improvements in system pressure and an end to service interruptions. This in turn will cause an 
increase in the generation of wastewater. Upgrades to the sewage network in Liaoyuan will help 
offset the wastewater increase in that city and Meihekou has completed a feasibility study report 
for a wastewater treatment plant which was recently approved. From a watershed perspective, 
the net impact of the Project will still be positive since pollutant loading reductions in Changchun 
exceed loading increases from these three cities.4 Moreover, the negative impact of higher 
wastewater effluent volumes will diminish over time as national wastewater treatment standards 
are implemented in urban areas.
